artefact: Driving lessons - who can teach you

artefact.overview: The rules for driving before you've passed your driving test and got a full licence, who can give you driving lessons, finding a driving instructor, practising with friends and family
artefact.body:
If you’re paying someone to teach you to drive they must be an approved driving instructor (ADI).

If you want to practise your driving with someone (without paying them) they must:

  • be over 21
  • be qualified to drive the type of vehicle you want to learn in (eg for a car with a manual or automatic gearbox)
  • have had their driving licence for 3 years

You must have a provisional driving licence for Great Britain or Northern Ireland when you’re learning to drive.

Approved driving instructors (ADIs)

ADIs are regulated by the Driving Standards Agency (DSA). Find your nearest ADI.

An ADI displays a green badge on the windscreen.

Driving with friends and relatives

If you’re driving a manual car, the person supervising you must have a manual licence.

If you drive without the right supervision you can be fined up to £1,000 and get 3 to 6 penalty points on your provisional licence.

‘L’ and ‘D’ plates

If you’re a learner driver you must put ‘L’ plates on prominent places on the front and back of your vehicle. You can use either ‘L’ or ‘D’ plates in Wales.
